frameDefinitions: A Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act.
The  Speaker expresses through language his wish to get the Addressee to act in some way that will help to bring about events or states described in the Content.
A Manipulator gets his Victim to perform a Resulting_action against what their better judgment would have been at the time.
A Speaker succeeds in getting an Addressee to believe or plan to execute the Content the Speaker has in mind.
An Agent intentionally seeks to bring about an internal mental or emotional state in the Experiencer.
frameExamples: You think I <t>talked</t> Peter into giving me those earrings, don't you?
Mr Smithers always <t>encourages</t> the employees to stay late and work harder.
Are you trying to tell me that Ace <t>blackmailed</t> you into becoming his lover?
At one point, Walter tries to <t>convince</t> his wife that he has had a story accepted by BBC Radio.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part  that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.
The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> talks the <fen>Addressee</fen> into performing the <fen>Content</fen>.
The wish for action on the Addressee's part that the Speaker expresses.
The person that the <fen>Speaker</fen> seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
What the communication is about.
The written or spoken material that contains a message that potentially influences the <fen>Addressee</fen> towards the <fen>Content</fen>.
An entity which the <fen>Speaker</fen> believes should participate in the action.
The time at which the lobbying occurs.
The location where the <fen>Speaker</fen> attemtps susaion on an <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The person who gets the Victim to act against their interest.
The person who the Manipulator gets to do something they would not have done had no pressure or deception been applied.
What the <fen>Manipulator</fen> intends to make the <fen>Victim</fen> do and the <fen>Victim</fen> actually does.
The role goods is anything (including labor, time, or legal rights) that can be taken away.
The time when the manipulation occurs.
The location where the <fen>Manipulator</fen> manipulates the <fen>Victim</fen>.
The person that the Speaker seeks to influence to act.
The person who intends through the use of language to get another person to act.
The wish for action on the <fen>Addressee</fen>'s part that the <fen>Speaker</fen> expresses.
A piece of written or spoken material that changes the mind of the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The general item or items that are the focus of the <fen>Content</fen> of the <fen>Speaker</fen>'s message.
When the <fen>Speaker</fen> suades the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the Speaker suades the Addressee.
The <fen>Agent</fen> is an External Argument of the target word and purposefully arouses an emotional state.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person the <fen>Agent</fen> causes to have a particular emotional state.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> affects the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> affects the <fen>Experiencer</fen>
listRoleExamples: Leslie blackmailed <fex>the watch</fex> out of John.
<fex>His speech</fex> convinced me to join the Peace Corps.
You haven't convinced me <fex>about that yet</fex>.
